[h1]Story[/h1]
Hades takes place in the Underworld as you control Zagreus, the son of none other than Hades himself, who has sought to escape his father's realm and seek his fortune on the surface.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3614351173

With the assistance of your mother, Nyx, Zagreus has gained the attention of Olympus, and the Gods there are offering their aid to his plight as well.

With countless foes ahead and the aid of the Gods, Zagreus must fight through the layers of the Underworld and seek his freedom at any cost. But what awaits him at the end of his journey?

[h1]Gameplay Analysis[/h1]
[h3]Traversing the hells.[/h3]
As with most action roguelike games, fast, frenetic gameplay and quick decision-making are what help define Hades.

Movement is fluid and simplistic but requires a level of experience to master. Traversing the landscapes can be treacherous at times, so understanding the controls is crucial.

Hades is fairly straightforward mechanically. You will face off against waves of enemies within each room and then are given a choice of two following rooms to enter, with their specific rewards for completion.

At the end of each floor, you are presented with a boss fight that is static for each level of the Underworld, and after this fight, you can ascend to the next level.

Dying means you have to start again from the beginning of the run.

[h3]Weapons fit for a God.[/h3]
In addition to the colossal amount of abilities and skills, you can unlock and discover across your playthrough. You will also get to choose from a selection of weapons that drastically change the way you play. The starting sword you have is a good all-rounder, but each weapon you unlock will have strengths and weaknesses you will have to discover and overcome to survive.

[h3]Power on speed dial.[/h3]
The part that makes Hades unique is the God's power mechanics, each of the Olympian Gods can give you a fraction of their power to use, across a selection of skills, randomised each time to three choices.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3614351557

Each of the Gods has a specific thing they can provide, such as Ares has a lot of offensive abilities, while Hermes can improve speed and dodging.

Blending these with your choice of weapon and playstyle can be a lot of fun, especially experimenting with what works and what doesn't.

[h1]Audio and Visual[/h1]
Not the most impressive visual experience on the market, but one of the most unique. The art style is chocked full of character, detail and expression that you immediately feel pulled into the story purely based on a visual sense.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3614352429

The audio is much the same, not particularly redefining anything, but is loaded with its style and personality that it's hard to not feel connected with it. In cooperation with the visual style, these aspects work extremely well together.

[h1]Steam Deck Performance and Specifications[/h1]
Hades performs extremely well on the Steam Deck, and I'd probably go as far as to say that this is a staple for the hardware. At full charge, you'd get two to three hours of gameplay out of it, which is decent considering the style of the game.

[h1]Final Thoughts - Excellent[/h1]
[url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2529084785]Review chart here.[/url]
Hades is a phenomenal game that plays extremely well and consistently provides a fun, fast and frenetic gameplay experience that is loaded with character and story. Aiming for 100% completion does weigh the game down considerably, but the general experience with the game was nothing but high. I definitely recommend this game to anyone who is a fan of good stories, roguelites or unique art styles.

After I heard about Hades 2 finally coming out of early access, I thought I'd give Hades another shot. When the game came out on Switch, I bought it - then promptly got stuck due to the limitations of the Joycons. Got it on a nice sale, and got to say that after 150 hours, it's an excellent use of that time.

Beating the game took a long time, but after I beat the final boss the first time, that's when the real game starts. I probably did around 50-60 clears to get all of the achievements, but I could have probably done it faster if I tried to optimize. However, why would I try to optimize? This game is super fun to play with all of the different permutations from boons, weapons, and pact of punishment modifiers. I'd be able to make a lot of my own goals for getting through a run, and even did some light speed-running (18 minutes or so is speed-running for me :D).

Art style? Great. Music? Maybe unbeaten in terms of the variety of music that is available. Seriously, some of the singing was weirdly good from Orpheus. Themes and storyline about family and rekindling relationships? More wholesome than I realized it was going to be. Theseus being annoying and Zagreus picking up on it and roasting him? Funny. 

Many of the creative aspects of this game should be a standard for what games can do with early access feedback: have a strong core idea, then refine and polish for as long as humanly possible. You can really tell Supergiant took their time with this, and that's why it won a bazillion awards.

There are some things that I think could have been explained a bit better to the player. Some of the conversations and side-quests seem to happen in a random order, but to get all of the achievements I had to max out conversations with certain characters. Thanatos, for example, just stopped appearing until another quest was completed, but I was trying to max rank his relationship for his companion buddy. Also,   wish that the weapons were easier to unlock and use earlier on - I finally got some of the sweetest aspects towards the end of the game when I no longer needed them. 

Overall, very important game to set the standard of work that can go into polishing a release - and also just a very fun top-down roguelike that teaches you to stick with it and eventually you can get that same Souls-like gratification out of it.

Let's preface this simply by saying, I enjoyed my first 50 hours with this game. Interesting character dynamics, fun varied combat, challenging but satisfying combat, all around I enjoyed nearly all of that 50 hours; But you wanna know why I have an extra 30 hours? 

Achievement hunting, specifically ONE Achievement. Now, I'll be the bigger man and won't spoil what it was, but I'll explain a bit about this game's rouge-like element. Each of the games zones are made out of rooms. Combat, challenges, survive etc. There's a particular type of room called Encounter Rooms. They often give great benefits. Issue is, they're also bloody rare. You can go 10-20 runs without seeing one. To get 3 achievements, you need to find each of the 3 zones encounter rooms and that's not all. Some of these achievements can only be done AFTER finishing the prior one so if you low-ball cant get a certain encounter in a previous zone, you're SOOL for a while. 

Worse part is, you can customize the difficulty of your runs, you can make Zagreus stronger or weaker as you see fit, but all that pales to the sheer fact you cant control Encounter Rooms. It's literal RNG baked into the game. So you really can't cheese this outside letting the mobs kill you after wasting 15 minutes into a run.

Overall, Great game but the encounter rooms made it overstay its welcome. Won't immediately try out Hades 2 now its fully released But I hope they did fix this of all things.

I want to like this game, but it feels too repetitive and one-note for me. Yes, there are a variety of weapons and boons, which alter your attack and defense mechanics, to unlock and explore. However, regardless of what you're using, the gameplay loop is simple -- Attack, dodge the ridiculous amounts of crap the game throws at you, attack, dodge, attack, dodge, dodge, dodge. No matter how many upgrades you collect, you never feel like a powerful character. Attacks barely chip away at the health of all but the weakest enemies, so every fight is a monotonous slog. And each time you die, you get a tiny little bit of story that seems to go nowhere, you put a few points into skill upgrades that seem to make little difference, any you go out and face the same groups of enemies again and again. Maybe the game gets better after hundreds of runs, but I just don't have the patience for that. I was hoping for something akin to the experience of a good rogue-like such as Binding of Isaac, or a good action-RPG like Diablo 2/3, where the experiences changes dramatically based on the items and abilities you find and/or choose. This is not that, so if that's what you're looking for, move along.

Let's preface this simply by saying, I enjoyed my first 50 hours with this game. Interesting character dynamics, fun varied combat, challenging but satisfying combat, all around I enjoyed nearly all of that 50 hours; But you wanna know why I have an extra 30 hours? 

Achievement hunting, specifically ONE Achievement. Now, I'll be the bigger man and won't spoil what it was, but I'll explain a bit about this game's rouge-like element. Each of the games zones are made out of rooms. Combat, challenges, survive etc. There's a particular type of room called Encounter Rooms. They often give great benefits. Issue is, they're also bloody rare. You can go 10-20 runs without seeing one. To get 3 achievements, you need to find each of the 3 zones encounter rooms and that's not all. Some of these achievements can only be done AFTER finishing the prior one so if you low-ball cant get a certain encounter in a previous zone, you're SOOL for a while. 

Worse part is, you can customize the difficulty of your runs, you can make Zagreus stronger or weaker as you see fit, but all that pales to the sheer fact you cant control Encounter Rooms. It's literal RNG baked into the game. So you really can't cheese this outside letting the mobs kill you after wasting 15 minutes into a run.

Overall, Great game but the encounter rooms made it overstay its welcome. Won't immediately try out Hades 2 now its fully released But I hope they did fix this of all things.
